thread.title: Vertu Motors hits record profit levels but drop in sterling delays acquisition plans

author: Jonathon Manning
title: Vertu Motors hits record profit levels but drop in sterling delays acquisition plans
text:

Vertu Motors has posted record breaking profits but said that the Brexit-hit pound was continuing to affect new car sales and had delayed its acquisition plans. 
The Gateshead-headquartered car dealership saw its profit before tax soar 29.4% to £24.2m during the six months ending August 31. 
A tight control on costs and increased margins helped Vertu achieve its profit figures, but ultimately the weak value of the pound led to increased new car prices, which impacted sales. 
The Brexit-hit pound also impacted the firm’s physical growth, with chief executive Robert Forrester admitting that its acquisition bids were beaten by overseas firms. 
Mr Forrester said: “We still kept looking at acquisitions that came across us but in some cases, and it comes down to currency a bit, some people saw better value in some of them so were bidding higher prices. They tended to be foreign investors who had the benefit of the currency. 
“It is a bit like buying used cars. If you overpay for a used car it is quite hard to sell it, and if you overpay for an acquisition it is quite hard to make money on it. So we have to be buying things at the right price. We are very focused on that. 
“It wasn’t that we were not looking for acquisitions, it was that we either felt that the price was too high or that the opportunity would be cheaper in the next 18 months.” 
Mr Forrester added that he expected the firm would make its next acquisition in the next 12 months, but said currently there was no news to announce. 
Overall Vertu’s turnover remained flat at £1.45bn during the six month perdiod. 
While sales of new cars decreased, Vertu’s sales of used cars increased by 1.1% on a like-for-like basis. This was the twelfth consecutive period the firm has seen an increase in its used car sales. Read More Debt-free degrees - and £18,000 salary - being offered by Gateshead firm 
Aftersales have also become an increasingly important aspect of Vertu’s business, accounting for 8% of turnover and over 40% of the group’s gross profit. Vehicle repairs and servicing was the main driver in the company’s aftersales operations, with like-for-like revenues growing by 4.4%. 
Earlier this year Vertu revealed it was launching a new apprenticeship scheme that would allow candidates to earn a debt-free degree while earning a £18,000 salary. 
The first intake of eight apprenticeships have now enrolled on the scheme, which is carried out in conjunction with Northumbria University. 
Following the results Vertu has increased its interim dividend by 10% to 0.55p per share. Like us on Facebook
